comments.commentBody: You are quite correct. Moreover, I've been to Auckland and can tell you it is widely regarded as the crossroads of the Pacific, a magnet for people from all over Polynesia. I even met a man at a bank who was from... drum roll...Suva, Fiji.

.
Thank you, perplejo.

Aren't you missing the State Fair, though?! ;-) It's all over the politics programs (I'm not watching them, just reading the descriptions).

Someday, I want to see the Butter Cow(s) in person.

BTW, a movie called "Butter" is set largely in what is supposed to be Johnson County. One look tells you it's not Johnson County; the whole thing was filmed in Louisiana. Fun film, not a classic.
Good grief. In general, we can't agree on what constitutes the MidWest in these United Statres! How can we be expected to define what constitutes the South Pacific?

SUVA is the largest city in the South Pacific? How can that be a good clue when by most standards it isn't even the largest city in Fiji! Nasinu is larger in some ways and not in others. It is the largest municipality:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasinu

That isn't my main beef, however. How is New Zealand not a South Pacific nation or for that matter Australia? Both have many cities larger than SUVA.

WMAR, wrt "Did you have a look at the EM Drive?"

Why are you shilling this, particularly as some sort of energy source?

It seems that you do not understand that while they claim to violate the conservation of momentum, they do not claim to violate the conservation of energy, and that this device produces no energy at all?

Indeed the power consumption was not disclosed. The thrust produced was not reproducible run-to-run, but never greater than the weight of a snowflake.

If you are not engaged in Mark Goldes' style fraud, then you are embarrassing yourself further ... if that is possible.

Lee,

Discussing is not "shilling" is it? When you take a view or offer a thought, are you "shilling"? Moreover, why end your comment with a personal attack? I thought, and think, the EM drive is exciting and has shown enough to remain on the table. SO do lots of others, including very fine scientists. I don't consider then "shilling" either.

1. You're not gonna explain what the heck this has to do with power generation, are you? Or is this jist one of those things where because the Enterprise has warp engines, you figure that's where the power comes for Beverly Crusher's hair dryer?

2. You're getting called a shill because of a) your general shilling for oil and coal and the right wing, and b) your cheerleading in wildly-exaggerated terms for an interesting poece of tech that is nowhere near as far along as you're pretending.

3. How are these two connected? By the fact that your far-right, laissez-faire economics depend on a culture of excess and waste and endless frontier. Therefore, it becomes essential that you a) cheerlead for wasteful and obsolete technologies like coal and oil, and b) cheerlead for iffy technologes that encourage us to go right on wasting and stuffing ourselves.

4. Not incidentally, this relates directly to your beef with Pope Francis: like the Dalai Lama, he's developed a nasty habit of saying that piling up more junk and running around screaming in a big truck like a child won't make you happy or healthy.

5. I did, however, enjoy your chanting your usual pieties about supporting science and scientists and research--as long as you agree with them, of course.

Hey, a brief FYI: science, history, literature and the arts that we agree with all the time aren't doing their job.

I would be quite pleased if funding could be arranged for this arc fusion reactor to be fully engineered and a research version built and tested. But based on prior experience with matters nuclear that will take 20 to 30 years to qualify the concept.

We need to begin full deployment of what we have now, now.

Made as directed it needed more flavor--next time I will add anchovies to the garlic and oil.  I also added a bag of spincach--half to the last minute of cooking the pasta and the other half mixed with the garlic and oil and then through the hot pasta on top.

Greg must be a far-right guy to think the NDP is far left.  But Greg, pay attention to the damage Harper's tactics do to your democracy.  That's the key.  He's one of those like Orban in Hungary and Modi in India who are sneakily taking away democracy.

This young woman rejoiced and praised God at the cold blooded murders of 5 US servicemen? That is beyond immature youth - that shows a complete and utter lack of empathy. She cannot imagine the suffering of those who were murdered, nor can she imagine the suffering of their families, their loved ones, who now confront the abyss of grief? What has happened to create such callousness?

Furthermore, to not know what ISIS does seems utterly impossible. This is an issue of basic character - even if one agrees with ideology, to believe that mass murder, mass rape, and violence, is justified is just plain wrong. There is no justification for mass murder, mass rape and this level of violence. None whatsoever.

.
Martin, Mr. Krozel was quite specific about the third animal having a 2-word name.

Clearly a Cob is an animal. What else could it possibly mean? A Cat is also an animal. And a Bobcat is an animal. (Also: Cougar, Puma, Mountain Lion, Nittany Lion, et others.)

I am amazingly confident that you can find an ancient scroll on which all the writing is worn away ... but there are traces of what seems like it could have been "bob cat". And I know that such a wordless scroll would be sufficient support for calling Bobcat a two-word answer (in accordance with the standards of clue-support I have read in prior Comment threads).

But in your Reply, you used one word ("bobcat"). You agree with the National Basketball Association (and probably the National Bible Association, but check with Deb on that.)

Bobcat is one word, like "LeBron". "Honey bear" is 2 words, like "King James".

Besides, stop it with these PUT ONS! (I am parsing "PUT ONS" and "SHORT TON" as 2-word phrases spaced as I have typed them. Your kilometerage, as always, may vary. The kilometerage of the long-suffering Elaine definitely varies; she doesn't read instructions. And by "instructions", I mean the blah blah of Messrs. Krozel and Shortz, available on audio and in transcribed form, about the 3rd animal having a 2-word name.)

We all look forward to tales of La Push.

When you decide to join our enemy you are our enemy. Better to arrest you now that deal with you later.

You do not have a right to live in America and join our enemy. Thoughts are different from actions and actions begin with planning.
I would not arrest them.  i would help them on their way and They should not be permitted to return.  Decisions have consequences.
Sadly, a crime is anything the FBI says it is.

I join those concerned that these kinds of arrests constitute government overreach. It should not be a crime to sympathize with any cause, no matter how grotesque. How do we know if they ever would have acted without having been enticed by the FBI? How do we know they wouldn't have arrived in the Middle East, been quickly disillusioned with the gap between their ideal of ISIS and the dirty reality, and been on the next plane home? We should not be in the business of predicting criminal intent; this is not The Minority Report. Keep a close eye on them, by all means, but only arrest and punish them when they have clearly committed a crime.

We can thank AnDREa Bocelli for getting the stress down. It seems like before he came on the scene the ship was often the ANdrea DOria.

Someone named Andrea posted a comment here recently related to the Italian language. I went away scratching my head over that person's gender.

I remember seeing an American reporter named ANdrea interviewing AnDREa Bocelli. Yes, she got his name right!

We live in an era where we see "young people" in a softer focus than is necessary, especially in situations such as these. The Boston bombers were "young," as have been numerous American teens who, in the past, were conspiring to blow up something or the other. Ideology and a meaningful cause that is bigger then our day to day, often tedious, middle class lives, can be powerful gravitational fields for youth. The young can pose significant threats to national security when sufficiently seduced by the allure of power and personal adventure. Recruits, whether for the army or the militia or terrorist groups like ISIS, will inevitably be the youth. So why be surprised by the youth and "innocence" of these two?

Letting these two head off to Syria would be a much worse punishment for their foolishness than anything that could happen to them here, but I sure hope we did not waste time, effort and money on entrapment....
A cold hand up for thinking ASL at 20D, but my thought was GLOVES, which didn't fit.  Where's Johnny Cochran when you need him?

I usually love Jeff Chen's puzzles. He really takes care to minimize the junk fill and maximize good word play. His clues and answers often have a very snappy quality that I enjoy. He is also a master of misdirection.

When I do a Chen puzzle I usually reset myself for lots of misleads. In a way, that hurt me in this puzzle. I was sure that "things removed before signing" would be "mittens", a nod to sign language. I was also sure that the answer "go after" was too simple. I was looking for too much in both cases, and this threw me for a while. Meanwhile, other parts of the puzzle did not disappoint. Only realized that I was a dodo on Oto until reading the notes. Great misdirection on cub's supporters. Was so hung up on sports that even as I got the word bears, I wondered what the Chicago Bears had to do with the Cubs?

Agree with Kiki below that the clue for SUVA was weak. That was my only gripe with an excellent puzzle.

Thanks Wags, for pointing out the additional stuff on Xwordinfo.

.
I expected you would feel that way, Leapy, but my esteem for you, and Martin, is such that agreeing on such points matters little in the overall scheme -- and disagreeing would make no difference.

I suppose my passions and my accustomed lack of brevity were fueled by reading both of Harper Lee's Maycomb books in the past month.
Oh, I don't disagree with the technical correctness of the clue, MTFT. I just think it's ill-advised as a focal distinction of humanity.

.
Oh Leapy! You Quebecois and your fascinating metrics for evaluating clues, always beyond my ken.

Plus the bilingualism! Drinking du "the" and exchanging mots "just"e ...

I agree with 90% of what Liz B said! I have other stuff to say, but some blog-followers may not like it. Possibly a good move would be, not reading. We are here for fun.

I look for, and find, things to like in most puzzles. Sometimes, I was the only one who liked a specific puzzle! I am fine with people not liking a puzzle; but I voice my ideas. An example was the "AROUND THE WORLD IN 80 DAYS" puzzle; many dissed it, but I was awestruck, and I explained my reasons. I could have told the critics, "don't criticize, it's only a puzzle"; but I don't think I did so.

More recently, 2 of us stated what we disliked about a puzzle. Many people seemed bothered by my posts. So I say again: some may not like what follows. It is harsh criticism of a word.

The last word to fall for me was GRIDS. S in GRIDS crossed 50 Across (clue: "Makeup of humanity"; accepted answer: RACES). I paused and hoped RACES was not the intended answer. I know there is support in books for that answer to that clue, if that's what matters. But I frequently comment on nytimes.com to oppose people who choose to divide humanity into RACES. WE here, we happy few, are verbal, and some words do not fit: Humanity is made up of one RACE, not "RACES".

Disagree if you wish! I'm no THOUGHT POLICE, and I oppose THOUGHT POLICE! But the sooner word-people stop saying "humanity" is "ma[d]e up" of "RACES", the better it'll be for others who use words less precisely than we.

One hopes that, in time, they will catch on. :-)
Bank of America should be in the graveyard of history, along with its corrupt board.
nora - They would be, were it not for the herculean efforts of their lawyers; they should be broken up (along with the other TBTF's) and the board should be replaced for its skulduggery.

I was going to comment on the "inbreeding" of major companies Boards as you did. I agree completely that they have got each other's backs and the process has been co-opted to their own thirst for power and greed. It was my understanding that the CEO "reported to the board" so that there was some level of oversight of the CEO. Well, if he's the Chairman of the Board, as well as CEO, there is no oversight.

Regrettably, what's seen at BAC is a replay of what's seen all across the corporate landscape, as the Fortune 500 boards of directors have abandoned representing shareholders, instead acting as 500 different CEO Union locals, comprised of the various CEOs' buddy CEOs.

The oh-so-thin veneer of compensation consultants' recommendations for ever higher levels of CEO shareholder extortion becomes ever harder to stomach, illustrating in living color the soft bigotry of low expectations.

It is admirable BAC is still standing, but anyone who can do a Google search logically questions why management thinks they should be lauding themselves in SEC filings instead of the long-suffering shareholders - although, BAC's large army of very very well-compensated lawyers certainly doesn't get enough credit for its upright vs. prone posture.

Unless these two enter some very quick guilty pleas, they will not be talking about their motives any time soon.  As for why people are speculating about what their motives were, speculation is a natural reaction when people do not have any information.

@TM: "In the 1930s, impressionable young folks joined or became fellow travelers to communism, ..."

That was during the Depression, when the Soviet Union seemed to offer job opportunities. Unfortunately, the people looking for work there ended up in Stalin's prison system. See:
"The forsaken : an American tragedy in Stalin's Russia" by Tim Tzouliadis.

They were not going to fight in the French Foreign Legion to protect the Congo from warlords or some such.  They were going to join a monstrous, borderless terrorist organization that is actively at war with the U.S. and kidnaps and rapes indiscriminately, with a preference for U.S. citizens.

I fail to understand this. If you want to leave the US, and fight for another country, who cares? I'd say good riddance. Encourage it! Why is it our business to prevent someone from moving? Take their passport if they pledge allege cue to another country, and call it a day?

A young woman just graduated from high school falls under the sway of political extremism, naively suggesting to the on-line stranger "that she might be able to offer 'medical aid' to the cause."  Yes, I know that we need to protect ourselves from home-grown terrorists, but this sounds more like The Prime of Miss Jean Brodie than a federal case.  We'll see how her obvious entrapment defense works out.

Perfect. Grilled a 1 lb outer skirt steak. Only 3 minutes needed per side and it was tender. Only marinated for 45 minutes and was delicious and tasty, but longer could've been better. Guesstimated paste portions but the puree was delicious.  Would've used any leftover on chicken.

The FBI recognized her chatter on social media. Media coverage of beheadings of innocent people & reports of rape seem so unreal, there are young people convinced ISIS is misunderstood. Because of free speech, I doubt there's anything the authorities can do legally to educate these misguided people; it seems like the only legal action is arresting them when they commit illegal acts. Wish we could place them in cities or other countries where they can help suffering people.
But even if  prostitution is inherently demeaning (a proposition with which I disagree) it would be less demeaning, and safer, if it were legal.

Hi Faith,

Both the Boston Marathon Bombers and the Chatanooga shooters were not well adjusted. The Boston Marathon Bombers were from a family with domestic violence, and lived on public assistance. Some think the older brother was psychotic. The Chatanooga bomber, while well educated, had substance abuse problems, a life time of depression, and could not hold a job.
Well written, Faith!

"We need to learn the telltale signs, recognize seemingly benign complaints about our norms and mores."
That is really, really, dangerous.

It is unfortunately not surprising that there are individuals living in America, yet loathing our culture and our people.  It is, however, unexpected and desperately alarming that such include young Americans with celebrated upbringing and promising and bright futures: either converts or those born into the Islamic faith but seamlessly navigating the culture of the West. This is not the first time we hear it being a popular, social, athletic, and reportedly well-adjusted young person: the Boston Marathon bombers, the Chattanooga shooter; and now this.  It is truly so difficult to imagine someone who outwardly embraced the social fabric of the West, yet in the quiet of his mind, held a shredded view of everything outside the home and the mosque. It's easier to imagine a disaffected teenage convert, caught up in the euphoria of new-found faith, and a zeal to impress the new-found group.  It makes one wonder what goes on behind the closed doors of homes, the talk around the kitchen table that stays within the walls.  We need to learn the telltale signs, recognize seemingly benign complaints about our norms and mores. Still, I feel for the Muslims who truly mean no harm,  have not a bone in their bodies that could ever take a life, that could find something as vulgar as ISIS to be of any appeal.   It is Muslims making it difficult for Muslims to live in the West.

It's hard to know what they believed or didn't believe was true about ISIL as presented by the FBI. But it's clear that the notion that two such promising young Americans could turn to such evil is nearly beyond our own ability to comprehend it and almost too painful to readily accept. I may be naive, but I would have preferred to see their families alerted and steps taken to stop them and redeem them if possible.
Better than 20 years in prison would be a shorter term with the chance to learn from these two about what made them go down such a wrong path.

Sophie, I think your calculus is WAY off. Hotels may not have screened all employees? What makes you think Airbnb has screened even a fraction of the millions of hosts worldwide?
And hotels, particularly in major worldwide chains, come well underwritten with liability insurance. The insurance underwriters, even abroad, put a major limitation on hotel carelessness. Airbnb looks at you and tells you you're on your own. There is ZERO warranty from Airbnb that the host awaiting you isn't the next Jeffrey Dahmer. In fact, what better side work for a serial killer than an Airbnb host?

These two are the doe eyed people who get training and fly planes into buildings.
These two young people have ruined their lives, but did not get the chance to ruin others. Let's thank the FBI for rooting them out before they could contribute to the brutality.
